facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 41 to 49 of 1962 in Civil Appellate Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 41 to 49 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 23, 1959 of the Orissa High Court in O. J. C. No 33 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the. judgment and order dated July 23, 1959, of the Orissa High Court in O. J. C. No 33 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 5, 1963 by SARKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. April 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.-

facts.text: Appellant entered into a contract with Hindusthan Steel Private Ltd. for the manufacture and supply of bricks at Rourkela in Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had entered into a companytract with a companypany called the Hindusthan Steel Private Ltd., for the manufacture and supply of bricks at Rourkela in Orissa.

facts.text: Large quantities of bricks were manufactured and supplied under the contract and the appellant received payment for them.

anchor.surface_text: Large quantities of bricks were manufactured and supplied under the companytract and the appellant received payment for them.

facts.text: Respondent State assessed the appellant to sales tax under the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 on these supplies on the basis that they were sales.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent State assessed the appellant to sales tax under the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 on these supplies on the basis that they were sales.

facts.text: Appellant contended that the contract was only for labour or for work done and material found, and that there was no sale of any goods.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytended that the companytract was only for labour or for work done and material found, and that there was really numbersale of any goods on which the tax companyld be levied.

facts.text: Appellant moved the High Court of Orissa for a writ of mandamus directing the respondent State not to assess or levy the tax.

anchor.surface_text: He moved the High Court of Orissa for a write of mandamus directing the res- pondent State number to assess or levy the tax.

facts.text: Application for writ rejected in limine by the Orissa High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The application was rejected in limine by the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to this Court (Supreme Court).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has number companye to this Court in further appeal.

facts.text: Contract clause: land will be given free (for earth to make bricks).

anchor.surface_text: This companytention is founded on a clause in the companytract which says., land will be given free and which was apparently intended to make the earth available to the appellant for making the bricks.

facts.text: Court finding: clause meant property in earth transferred to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree that this clause proved that the earth all along companytinued to belong to the Company. It seems to us that when the clause said, land will be given, it meant that the property in the earth to be dug out for making the bricks would be transferred to the appellant.

facts.text: Bricks supplied were different from earth; property in bricks passed to company.

anchor.surface_text: Again what was supplied to the Company by the appellant was number the earth which be got from it but bricks, which we think, are something entirely different.

facts.text: Contract provided bricks remain at appellant's risk till delivery to the Company.

anchor.surface_text: Further we find that the companytract provided that the bricks would remain at the appellants risk till delivery to the Company.

facts.text: Appellant could not sell bricks to other parties without permission of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: Another clause provided that the appellant would number be able to sell the bricks to other parties without the permission of the Company.

facts.text: In tender, appellant tendered for supply of materials described as bricks, with quantities and rates.

anchor.surface_text: Then we find that in the tender which the appellant submitted and the acceptance of which made the companytract, he stated, II we hereby tender for the supply to the Hindusthan Steel Private Ltd. of the materials described in the undermentioned memorandum. The memorandum described the materials as bricks, and also stated the Quantities to be delivered and the Rate at which materials are to be supplied.

facts.text: Contract payment: 75% of value paid when bricks stacked at kiln site, 25% on full delivery.

anchor.surface_text: The same companyclusion follows from another provision in the companytract which states that if bricks are stacked in a specified manner then 75 of the value of the bricks at kiln site will be measured and paid The balance of 25 will be paid finally when all the bricks have been delivered Only full bricks as finally delivered will be taken into account

facts.text: Appellant filed appeals against assessment orders to Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, which failed.

anchor.surface_text: It was said that before the High Court was moved under Art. 226 for the writ, the appellant had filed appeals against the orders of assessment to the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal. These appeals failed

facts.text: Appellant's application for reference to High Court by Tribunal rejected.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellants application for an order on the Tribunal to refer to the High Court the question of law raised in this appeal was also rejected by the High Court.

facts.text: This Court granted special leave to appeal from High Court's order refusing writ before Tribunal appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: But it appears that this Court had granted leave to appeal from the High Courts order refusing to issue the writ before the appeal to the tribunal had been dismissed.

facts.text: Court held the contract was for sale of bricks, transfer of property for consideration.

anchor.surface_text: All these provisions plainly show that the companytract was for sale of bricks. If it were so, the property in the bricks must have been in the appellant and passed from him to the Company.

facts.text: Sales tax defined as transfer of property in goods for cash or deferred payment or other valuable consideration.

anchor.surface_text: Now a sale which can be taxed under the Act has been defined as Any transfer of property in goods for cash or deferred payment or other valuable companysideration.

facts.text: Preliminary objection by respondent that appeal barred due to prior Tribunal proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: It remains number to numberice a preliminary objection to this appeal raised by the respondent.

facts.text: Court rejected preliminary objection as leave granted earlier.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companyld have appealed from the High Courts order refusing to direct a reference of the question but he chose to prosecute the appeal against the order in the petition for the writ which would have given him the same relief. Either remedy was open to him and neither can be said in the circumstances to be barred by the other.
The respondent State assessed the appellant to sales tax under the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 on these supplies on the basis that they were sales.

concepts.interpretation: Court upheld assessment under this Act on the basis that supplies constituted sales involving transfer of property in goods.

concepts.interpretation: Applied to hold that contract involved transfer of property in bricks from appellant to company for consideration, constituting a taxable sale.

concepts.unlisted_description: Defined in Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 as transfer of property in goods for consideration

anchor.surface_text: In these cases in arriving at the view that the contract was not for sale of goods the test that was applied is, what was the essence of the contract ? Was it the intention of the parties in making the contract that a chattel should be producedand transferred as a chattel for a consideration? This test has not been accepted as of general application to decide whether a contract was for sale of goods or for labour supplied and materials found

concepts.interpretation: Court applied test to hold essence of contract was transfer of bricks as chattels qua chattels for consideration, not mere labour; distinguished from printing book or painting portrait.

concepts.unlisted_description: Test to distinguish contract for sale of goods from contract for work/labour and materials found: whether intention was to produce and transfer chattel qua chattel

anchor.surface_text: It remains now to notice a preliminary objection to this appeal raised by the respondent. It was said that before the High Court was moved under Art. 226 for the writ, the appellant had filed appeals against the orders of assessment to the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal. These appeals failed and the appellants application for an order on the Tribunal to refer to the High Court the question of law raised in this appeal was also rejected by the High Court.

concepts.interpretation: Court rejected objection, holding that statutory appeal to Tribunal/reference and writ petition under Art. 226 were alternative remedies, neither barring the other; special leave already granted.

issues.text: whether the contract was for a transfer of property in the bricks from the appellant to the Company for a consideration

anchor.surface_text: The point at issue is whether the companytract was for a transfer of property in the bricks from the appellant to the Company for a companysideration.

issues.text: even if the earth of which the bricks had to be made be taken to have been transferred under the contract to the appellant, this was not a contract for sale of goods but one of work done and materials found

anchor.surface_text: The other argument of learned counsel for the appellant was that even if the earth of which the bricks had to be made be taken to have been transferred under the companytract to the appellant, this was number a companytract for sale

anchor.surface_text: It remains now to notice a preliminary objection to this appeal raised by the respondent. It was said that before the High Court was moved under Art. 226 for the writ, the appellant had filed appeals against the orders of assessment to the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal.

arguments.claim: the bricks had all along been its property and there could be no transfer of property in them to it

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the bricks were made out of earth belonging to the Company and, therefore, the bricks had all along been its property and there could be no transfer of property in them to it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: for a transfer of property in the bricks from the appellant to the Company for a companysideration. It is said that the bricks were made out of earth

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel stressed the fact that the contract nowhere used the word sale in connection with the supply of the bricks, in support of his argument that there was no sale.

anchor.surface_text: Before we leave this part of the case we have to notice the decision in P. A. Raju Chettiar v. The State of Madras 1 , to which learned counsel for the appellant referred.

arguments.claim: cases like Clay v. Yates and Robinson v. Graves show contract not for sale but work done; essence test: intention to produce and transfer chattel qua chattel?

anchor.surface_text: A contract of this kind is illustrated by the case of Clay v. Yates 1 . There the contract was to print a book, the printer to find the materials including the paper. Robinson v. Graves 2 , was also referred to.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ent case are different and for the reasons earlier mentioned, justify the view that here there was a transfer of the property in the earth to the appe

arguments.court_reasoning: Test not of general application; here intention clearly to transfer bricks qua chattels; essence delivery of bricks, not manufacture; skill incidental

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended that the contract was only for labour or for work done and material found, and that there was really no sale of any goods on which the tax could be levied.

arguments.court_reasoning: Definition of sale applies: transfer of property in bricks for consideration; contract provisions show property passed

arguments.claim: All these provisions plainly show that the contract was for sale of bricks. If it were so, the property in the bricks must have been in the appellant and passed from him to the Company

anchor.surface_text: All these provisions plainly show that the contract was for sale of bricks. If it were so, the property in the bricks must have been in the appellant and passed from him to the Company.

holdings.text: All these provisions plainly show that the contract was for sale of bricks. If it were so, the property in the bricks must have been in the appellant and passed from him to the Company.

anchor.surface_text: All these provisions plainly show that the companytract was for sale of bricks. If it were so, the property in the bricks must have been in the appellant and passed from him to the Company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract terms on risk, sale restriction, tender for supply of bricks as materials, and payment on delivery indicate property in bricks vested in appellant and transferred to company for consideration.

holdings.text: when the clause said, land will be given, it meant that the property in the earth to be dug out for making the bricks would be transferred to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree that this clause proved that the earth all along companytinued to belong to the Company. It seems to us that when the clause said, land will be given, it meant that the property in the earth to be dug out for making the bricks would be transferred to the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpretation of contract clause providing land free shows transfer of property in earth to appellant, as rate quoted accounts for free earth.

holdings.text: bricks could not remain at the appellants risk unless they were his property.

anchor.surface_text: Further we find that the companytract provided that the bricks would remain at the appellants risk till delivery to the Company. Now, obviously bricks companyld number remain at the appellants risk unless they were his property. Another clause provided that the appellant would number be able to sell the bricks to other parties without the permission of the Company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract risk and sale restriction clauses imply ownership of bricks by appellant prior to delivery.

holdings.text: it is not necessary that to constitute a sale, the word sale has to be used.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel stressed the fact that the contract nowhere used the word sale in connection with the supply of the bricks, in support of his argument that there was no sale. But it is not necessary that to constitute a sale, the word sale has to be used.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of 'sale' word irrelevant; substance of transfer of property for consideration determines sale.

holdings.text: under the contract there was a transfer of property in the bricks for consideration and, therefore, a sale notwithstanding that the word sale was not used.

anchor.surface_text: We have said enough to show that under the companytract there was a transfer of property in the bricks for companysideration and, therefore, a sale notwithstanding that the word sale was number used.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative contract provisions establish transfer of property in goods (bricks) for consideration, fitting statutory definition of sale.

holdings.text: This test has not been accepted as of general application to decide whether a contract was for sale of goods or for labour supplied and materials found.

anchor.surface_text: In these cases in arriving at the view that the contract was not for sale of goods the test that was applied is, what was the essence of the contract ? Was it the intention of the parties in making the contract that a chattel should be producedand transferred as a chattel for a consideration? This test has not been accepted as of general application to decide whether a contract was for sale of goods or for labour supplied and materials found

holdings.reasoning_summary: Essence test cited in precedents not universally applicable; cited authorities like Benjamin on Sales confirm.

holdings.text: the intention of the parties in making the contract clearly was that the Company would obtain delivery of the bricks to be made by the appellant it was a contract for the transfer of chattels qua chattels. The essence of the contract was the delivery of the bricks... The present case, therefore, must a fortiori be one of sale of goods.

anchor.surface_text: Here the intention of the parties in making the companytract clearly was that the Company would obtain delivery of the bricks to be made by the appellant it was a companytract for the transfer of chattels qua chattels. The essence of the companytract was the delivery of the bricks, though numberdoubt they had to be manufactured to a certain specification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing printing/painting contracts; here essence is delivery of standardized bricks as chattels, skill incidental; analogies to tailor/shoemaker support sale.

holdings.text: Either remedy was open to him and neither can be said in the circumstances to be barred by the other.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companyld have appealed from the High Courts order refusing to direct a reference of the question but he chose to prosecute the appeal against the order in the petition for the writ which would have given him the same relief. Either remedy was open to him and neither can be said in the circumstances to be barred by the other.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Writ petition under Art. 226 and statutory reference appeal are alternative remedies; pursuit of one does not bar the other, especially as special leave granted prior to tribunal outcome.

precedents.cited_proposition: no transfer of property in goods and thus no sale where merchant delivers silver to workmen who manufacture utensils and return them, as weight debited and credited back and only labour paid
precedents.cited_holding: there was no sale of the silver by the merchant to the workmen

precedents.cited_proposition: contract to print a book, the printer to find the materials including the paper is a contract for work done and materials found, not sale of goods

precedents.cited_proposition: contract where person commissions artist to paint portrait of a lady, artist supplies paint and canvas and delivers completed picture, is not contract for sale of goods
precedents.cited_holding: the contract was not for sale of goods

precedents.cited_proposition: delivery of paint and canvas ancillary to contract to paint portrait
